articles.headline: The Damage of Card Rewards
articles.snippet: Fees that merchants build to cover rewards programs lead to higher prices, which are passed on to poorer consumers.
articles.abstract: Fees that merchants build to cover rewards programs lead to higher prices, which are passed on to poorer consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For several years, I’ve wondered whether my aggressive pursuit of credit card rewards made me a selfish consumer.

articles.headline: A Sri Lankan Underdog Battles Global Tea Giants
articles.snippet: Facing competition from global tea giants, a tea grower has followed other Sri Lankan businesses in becoming a specialist producer of exclusive products.
articles.abstract: Facing competition from global tea giants, a tea grower has followed other Sri Lankan businesses in becoming a specialist producer of exclusive products.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Merrill J. Fernando’s eyes lit up one recent morning when his son Dilhan handed him a box of Twinings Pure White Tea. He quickly ripped open a tea bag and spilled its contents onto a piece of paper.

articles.headline: Across Divide in Iraq, a Sunni Courts Shiites
articles.snippet: A Sunni Muslim politician, Sheik Hamid al-Hais is an unlikely confederate of the Iraqi National Alliance, the Shiite standard-bearer in March elections.
articles.abstract: A Sunni Muslim politician, Sheik Hamid al-Hais is an unlikely confederate of the Iraqi National Alliance, the Shiite standard-bearer in March elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMADI, Iraq  In the unforgiving badlands of western Iraq’s Anbar Province, once a cradle of the insurgency and now a muddled landscape of corruption, simmering strife and spirited electoral campaigning, no one seems ready to pardon Hamid al-Hais.

articles.headline: Unions Rally to Oppose a Tax on Health Insurance
articles.snippet: Labor leaders say President Obama is betraying unions by supporting a tax on high-priced, employer-sponsored health insurance.
articles.abstract: Labor leaders say President Obama is betraying unions by supporting a tax on high-priced, employer-sponsored health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: When millions of blue-collar workers were leaning toward John McCain during the 2008 campaign, labor unions moved many of them into Barack Obama’s column by repeatedly hammering one theme: Mr. McCain wanted to tax their health benefits.

articles.headline: A Deluge of Devices for Reading and Surfing
articles.snippet: Dozens of companies, both well known and unknown, brought slender touch-screen tablets and electronic reading devices to the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
articles.abstract: Dozens of companies, both well known and unknown, brought slender touch-screen tablets and electronic reading devices to the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  You’ve heard of Amazon.com’s Kindle. And you probably know that Apple is likely to introduce a tablet computer this year. Soon you may also be hearing about the Alex, the Que proReader and the IdeaPad U1 Hybrid.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: China Tries a New Tack to Go Solar
articles.snippet: The country is taking tentative steps to master an alternative energy industry: using mirrors to capture sunlight, produce steam and generate electricity.
articles.abstract: The country is taking tentative steps to master an alternative energy industry: using mirrors to capture sunlight, produce steam and generate electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  As it moves rapidly to become the world’s leader in nuclear power, wind energy and photovoltaic solar panels, China is taking tentative steps to master another alternative energy industry: using mirrors to capture sunlight, produce steam and generate electricity.

articles.headline: Winter Breaks Budgets and Rules the Road
articles.snippet: In some parts of the country, streets are getting barely plowed and towns are running out of cleanup money.
articles.abstract: In some parts of the country, streets are getting barely plowed and towns are running out of cleanup money.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  There’s the gold standard of snow and ice removal on major roads in the Midwest  asphalt, plowed smooth and salted for easy driving.

articles.headline: Courts Roll Back Limits on Election Spending
articles.snippet: A series of decisions freeing corporations, unions and other interest groups from many restrictions could unleash a torrent of negative advertisements.
articles.abstract: A series of decisions freeing corporations, unions and other interest groups from many restrictions could unleash a torrent of negative advertisements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even before a landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance law expected within days, a series of other court decisions is reshaping the political battlefield by freeing corporations, unions and other interest groups from many of the restrictions on their advertising about issues and candidates.

articles.headline: Newly Frugal Generation Revives Discount Dining
articles.snippet: In Florida, early-bird specials have expanded beyond frugal retirees as younger diners tighten their budgets.
articles.abstract: In Florida, early-bird specials have expanded beyond frugal retirees as younger diners tighten their budgets.

articles.headline: Video Links Taliban in Pakistan to C.I.A. Attack
articles.snippet: A Jordanian suicide bomber said that his attack on C.I.A. operatives in Afghanistan last month was revenge for the killing of a Pakistani Taliban leader.
articles.abstract: A Jordanian suicide bomber said that his attack on C.I.A. operatives in Afghanistan last month was revenge for the killing of a Pakistani Taliban leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan  Humam Khalil Abu Mulal al-Balawi, the Jordanian suicide bomber who killed eight people at a Central Intelligence Agency outpost in Afghanistan last month, was shown in a video on Saturday saying that the attack was carried out in revenge for the 2009 killing of the Pakistani Taliban leader Baitullah Mehsud.

articles.headline: Officials Hid Truth of Immigrant Deaths in Jail
articles.snippet: Officials, some of them still on the job, used their role as overseers to cover up evidence of mistreatment of immigrants in federal custody.
articles.abstract: Officials, some of them still on the job, used their role as overseers to cover up evidence of mistreatment of immigrants in federal custody.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silence has long shrouded the men and women who die in the nation’s immigration jails. For years, they went uncounted and unnamed in the public record. Even in 2008, when The New York Times obtained and published a federal government list of such deaths, few facts were available about who these people were and how they died.

articles.headline: Banks Prepare for Big Bonuses, and Public Wrath
articles.snippet: The bank bonus season begins in earnest next week, and it looks as if it will be one of the largest and most controversial blowouts the industry has ever seen.
articles.abstract: The bank bonus season begins in earnest next week, and it looks as if it will be one of the largest and most controversial blowouts the industry has ever seen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone on Wall Street is fixated on The Number.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Ford’s Bet: It’s a Small World After All
articles.snippet: The new Focus is Ford’s first truly global car — a single vehicle designed and engineered for customers in every region of the world.
articles.abstract: The new Focus is Ford’s first truly global car — a single vehicle designed and engineered for customers in every region of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.

articles.headline: A Fox Chief at the Pinnacle of Media and Politics
articles.snippet: Roger Ailes has built Fox News into an earnings engine with powerful influence over the conservative movement.
articles.abstract: Roger Ailes has built Fox News into an earnings engine with powerful influence over the conservative movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2008, Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News, went to his boss, Rupert Murdoch, with two complaints: he had heard that Mr. Murdoch was considering endorsing Barack Obama for president in The New York Post, and he had read a book excerpt in Vanity Fair suggesting that Mr. Murdoch was sometimes embarrassed by the right-leaning Fox News.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Multicultural Critical Theory. At B-School?
articles.snippet: Business schools are realizing that students need to learn critical and creative thinking as much as finance.
articles.abstract: Business schools are realizing that students need to learn critical and creative thinking as much as finance.
articles.lead_paragraph: A DECADE ago, Roger Martin, the new dean of the Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto, had an epiphany. The leadership at his son’s elementary school had asked him to meet with its retiring principal to figure out how it could replicate her success.

articles.headline: Why All Earnings Are Not Equal
articles.snippet: When the market is roaring and the economy isn’t, smart investors should scrutinize how company profits are figured to make sure results justify higher valuations.
articles.abstract: When the market is roaring and the economy isn’t, smart investors should scrutinize how company profits are figured to make sure results justify higher valuations.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER a rip-roaring performance in 2009, the stock market has continued its upward climb. A reason to celebrate? Sure. But also a good time to check whether a company in which you have a stake keeps its books in a way that reflects reality.

articles.headline: Ballot Issues Attest to Anger in California
articles.snippet: In the midst of a fiscal meltdown and deteriorating services, voter initiatives seek to change the way the state does business.
articles.abstract: In the midst of a fiscal meltdown and deteriorating services, voter initiatives seek to change the way the state does business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  From San Diego to Mount Shasta, voters are expressing mounting disgust over California’s fiscal meltdown and deteriorating services, and they are offering scores of voter initiatives that seek to change the way the state does business.

articles.headline: Reid Apologizes for Remarks on Obama’s Color and ‘Dialect’
articles.snippet: Senator Harry Reid is quoted in a new book as saying that Barack Obama could become the first black president because he was “light-skinned” with “no Negro dialect.”
articles.abstract: Senator Harry Reid is quoted in a new book as saying that Barack Obama could become the first black president because he was “light-skinned” with “no Negro dialect.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, apologized on Saturday for once predicting that Barack Obama could become the country’s first black president because he was “light-skinned” and had “no Negro dialect, unless he wanted to have one.”

articles.headline: Military Is Awash in Data From Drones
articles.snippet: So much video intelligence is coming out of Afghanistan that military analysts are finding it hard to keep up.
articles.abstract: So much video intelligence is coming out of Afghanistan that military analysts are finding it hard to keep up.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Va.  As the military rushes to place more spy drones over Afghanistan, the remote-controlled planes are producing so much video intelligence that analysts are finding it more and more difficult to keep up.

articles.headline: Freeze Threatens Florida’s Tropical Fish
articles.snippet: Florida’s sizable tropical fish industry has suffered more than any other because of this year’s cold snap.
articles.abstract: Florida’s sizable tropical fish industry has suffered more than any other because of this year’s cold snap.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla.  Frosted oranges, strawberries encased in ice: the images of Florida’s freezes are familiar, sad and earthy. But just past the crop rows here in the state’s agricultural core, there swims another sizable industry that has suffered more than any other because of this year’s unusually long cold snap  tropical fish.

articles.headline: In Leno Fiasco, a Window to the Midlife Crisis of NBC
articles.snippet: Not since New Coke has a storied brand been so thoroughly maimed, and the situation suggests that networks mess with viewing habits at their peril.
articles.abstract: Not since New Coke has a storied brand been so thoroughly maimed, and the situation suggests that networks mess with viewing habits at their peril.
articles.lead_paragraph: The syndrome is a familiar one. Men of a certain age  and it is almost always men  wake up one day and find that they are no longer the center of the universe. Women fail to look their way, co-workers don’t scurry to fetch them coffee and bosses stop thinking of them as someone on the rise.

articles.headline: From Print to Phone to Web. And a Sale?
articles.snippet: Smartphones that can read bar codes are allowing magazines to add Internet-like interactivity to print graphics and advertisements.
articles.abstract: Smartphones that can read bar codes are allowing magazines to add Internet-like interactivity to print graphics and advertisements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Print may be a flat medium, but that has not stopped magazine publishers from trying to add dimension to their pages. For at least a decade, they have been experimenting with bar codes and icons that could take readers to Web sites, trying to add a bit of Internetlike interactivity to their pages.

articles.headline: Citing Hazard, New York Says Hold the Salt
articles.snippet: After initiating prominent campaigns against smoking and harmful trans fats, New York City has a new target: the food industry’s use of salt.
articles.abstract: After initiating prominent campaigns against smoking and harmful trans fats, New York City has a new target: the food industry’s use of salt.
articles.lead_paragraph: First New York City required restaurants to cut out trans fat. Then it made restaurant chains post calorie counts on their menus. Now it wants to protect people from another health scourge: salt.

articles.headline: NBC Confirms Its Late-Night Shake-Up
articles.snippet: Jay Leno will return to 11:35 p.m., but one question remains: whether Conan O’Brien will accept what amounts to a demotion.
articles.abstract: Jay Leno will return to 11:35 p.m., but one question remains: whether Conan O’Brien will accept what amounts to a demotion.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif.  NBC confirmed Sunday what the television world already knew  that the network would end Jay Leno’s prime-time show in one month and return him to 11:35 p.m., bumping “The Tonight Show” and its host, Conan O’Brien, to 12:05 a.m.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Considers Charity Requirement
articles.snippet: The firm may expand a program that requires executives to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity.
articles.abstract: The firm may expand a program that requires executives to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it prepares to pay out big bonuses to employees, Goldman Sachs is considering expanding a program that would require executives and top managers to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity.

articles.headline: How the AOL-Time Warner Merger Went So Wrong
articles.snippet: On the 10th anniversary of the merger, the executives responsible reflect on why they did it and why it failed.
articles.abstract: On the 10th anniversary of the merger, the executives responsible reflect on why they did it and why it failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, America Online merged with Time Warner in a deal valued at a stunning $350 billion. It was then, and is now, the largest merger in American business history.

articles.headline: Train Line Across the Balkans Restitches a Region
articles.snippet: The famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade has been revived, a sign the region’s isolation could be ending.
articles.abstract: The famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade has been revived, a sign the region’s isolation could be ending.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  The siege of Sarajevo had just begun the last time Vera Bagur, now 68, took the famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade. It was one of the few physical links that bound Muslims, Serbs and Croats.

articles.headline: Obama Weighs Tax on Banks to Cut Deficit
articles.snippet: With popular anger still simmering even after many banks have repaid bailout funds, the levies may deter future risky behavior as well as raise revenue.
articles.abstract: With popular anger still simmering even after many banks have repaid bailout funds, the levies may deter future risky behavior as well as raise revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will try to recoup for taxpayers as much as $120 billion of the money spent to bail out the financial system, most likely through a tax on large banks, administration and Congressional officials said Monday.
